info.game_comments:
Ed Schiffer game 5.
Last regular-play game of Season 9.

(1, 1).clue: In June this outlaw led The Sundance Kid and the rest of his gang in their first big train robbery

(2, 1).clue: In this mid-1980s this team from Edmonton won the NHL's Stanley Cup 4 years out of 5

(3, 1).clue: Like a rickshaw, a brouette was pulled by one of these

(4, 1).clue: For a time parsley & sage were used as remedies for this; now Minoxidil is giving it a try

(5, 1).clue: Broccoflower, a relatively new vegetable, is a cross between broccoli & this

(6, 1).clue: As a noun it's the horny sheath covering the toes of certain mammals; as a verb, it means "to dance"

(1, 2).clue: This state's first national park, Mount Rainier, was established

(2, 2).clue: Lyn St. James was named Rookie of the Year at this May 24, 1992 auto race, the first woman so honored

(3, 2).clue: The name of this Chinese sailing ship is derived from Portuguese & Javanese, not Chinese

(4, 2).clue: Roses, jasmine, and lavender have been used in this "therapy" as calming agents

(5, 2).clue: Beurre blanc is a classic French sauce whose name means this color butter

(6, 2).clue: To complain bitterly & loudly is to "raise" this

(1, 3).clue: William McKinley became the first sitting president to ride in a car when he took a spin in this "steamer"

(2, 3).clue: From 1976 to 1980, this Swede won 5 straight Wimbledon men's singles championships

(3, 3).clue: This wheeled seat attached to a motorcycle debuted circa 1903; the cocktail came later

(4, 3).clue: Span. missionaries in Peru found a substance in the bark of the Cinchona tree that treats this disease

(5, 3).clue: The last name of a nursery rhyme Jack, or a fish that's so high in fat he couldn't eat it

(6, 3).clue: This can be a careless mistake or a foolish person who might make one

(1, 4).clue: The marketer of a beverage called Grain-O acquired the rights to this dessert

(2, 4).clue: From 1964 through 1968, she was the U.S. women's figure skating champion

(3, 4).clue: The world's largest railway station, this U.S. landmark covers some 48 acres

(4, 4).clue: Although toxic, lily of the valley & oleander are plants that have been used to regulate this organ

(5, 4).clue: One of Post's Pebbles Cereals is named for this pet who lives in Bedrock

(1, 5).clue: Just days after he was found guilty in a retrial, this French Army Captain was pardoned

(2, 5).clue: While playing for this team, O.J. Simpson led the NFL in rushing yardage 4 times

(3, 5).clue: Reynolds Metals donated the Aluminaut, the 1st all-aluminum one of these, to the Science Museum of Virginia

(4, 5).clue: The Mexican yam yields diosgenin, a source for this arthritis-relieving steroid

(5, 5).clue: Popular in Pennsylvania, pepper pot is a peppery soup made from this stomach lining

(6, 5).clue: Accidental poisonings of kids under 5 have declined since this type of closure was introduced

(1, 1).clue: This island's harbor of Mandraki was once guarded by a colossal 120'-high statue

(2, 1).clue: This "low" clef is also known as the F clef

(3, 1).clue: The Bounty Islands of New Zealand were discovered by this Bounty captain in 1788

(4, 1).clue: Charles Bulfinch is famous for the beautiful houses he built on Beacon Hill in this city

(5, 1).clue: Margaret Truman's "Murder at the National Cathedral" opens in this city on a hot August morning

(6, 1).clue: Her brother and co-ruler Ptolemy XIII drowned in the Nile

(1, 2).clue: On his 1977 visit to Jerusalem, this Egyptian president prayed at the al-Aqsa mosque

(2, 2).clue: Messe des Morts is the French term for this kind of mass

(3, 2).clue: In 1889 Trinidad & this island became a single colony under British rule

(4, 2).clue: Palladio's architecture was a major influence on his design for Monticello

(5, 2).clue: Peter Straub & this master of horror were good friends long before they collaborated on "The Talisman"

(6, 2).clue: King Frederick Barbarossa drowned in 1190 while on the way to the third of these

(1, 3).clue: On October 3, 1935 this country invaded Ethiopia

(2, 3).clue: A ponticello is a little one of these found on a violin

(3, 3).clue: The Little Minch, a strait off Scotland, separates the "inner" and "outer" islands of this group

(4, 3).clue: One of Sir Edwin Lutyens' most important works was the layout for this Indian capital

(5, 3).clue: Kurt Vonnegut wrote "Breakfast of Champions" & he wrote "Breakfast at Tiffany's"

(6, 3).clue: His father, Carthaginian general Hamilcar Barca, drowned while besieging Helice in Spain

(1, 4).clue: Emir Abdur Rahman Khan rebuilt & modernized this Afghan capital in the 19th century

(2, 4).clue: In its homeland this choral group is known as Wiener Sangerknaben

(3, 4).clue: During the Spanish colonial period, this island was also known as Santo Domingo

(4, 4).clue: Arthur Charles Erickson's Simon Fraser Univ. overlooks this British Columbia city where he was born

(5, 4).clue: Rungstedlund, the Danish home where she wrote "Out of Africa", is now a museum

(6, 4).clue: This "good" Bohemian king had Saint John of Nepomuk drowned in the Moldau River in 1393

(1, 5).clue: This city, imperial capital of Japan before Tokyo, was spared bombing during WWII

(2, 5).clue: This composer's "Pomp and Circumstance" is a set of 5 marches; the first is the most famous

(3, 5).clue: This Canadian island is the fifth largest in the world

(4, 5).clue: The name of this influential German school means construction or architecture house

(5, 5).clue: Leon Uris titled Book I of this novel "Beyond Jordan"

(6, 5).clue: This member of the Bloomsbury literary group drowned herself March 28, 1941

(0, 0).clue: In 1992 Angela Bassett played the Jacksons' mother on TV & Betty Shabazz in this film
